gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Fish Predation on Juvenile Herring in Prince William Sound, Alaska, 2009-2012, EVOS Prince William Sound Herring Program

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Project overview on the Prince William Sound Science Center website.

The Prince William Sound population of Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) is considered resource that has not recovered from the effects of the 1989 oil spill. Numerous research and monitoring programs, funded in large part by the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, provide critical information about about herring populations in Prince William Sound.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The webpage for the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, which was formed to oversee restoration of the injured ecosystem through the use of the $900 million civil settlement, a part which funds Research, Monitoring, and Restoration programs in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Prior to use of this dataset please contact the Principal Investigator, Dr. Mary Anne Bishop as a courtesy and to ensure limitations to the data are appropriately considered in the context of their reuse. Final Report Citation: Bishop, M.A. and S.P. Powers. 2013. Top-down regulation by predatory fish on juvenile herring in Prince William Sound. Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Restoration Project Final Report (Project 10100132-G), Prince William Sound Science Center, Cordova, Alaska

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: These data are part of the Prince William Sound Herring Survey Program (EVOS project number 10100132-G), of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council which is a multi-faceted study to determine why herring populations in Prince William Sound remain depressed since the early 1990s. Our fish predators on juvenile herring project dataset is 11 comma-separated values (csv) files exported from a Microsoft Access database with a graphical relationship chart. The original dataset is also provided in Microsoft Acces(.acdb format). The data contain measurements of fish predator abundance and distribution in relation to juvenile herring in a series of bays in Prince William Sound during the 2009/10 through 2011/12 winters. Specifically, fish collections took place during November and March over three winters, beginning in November 2009 and ending March 2012. We deployed 79 longline sets including 61 sets at the five core bays (Eaglek, Lower Herring, Simpson, Whale, and Zaikof). Longlines were set near schools of herring located during hydroacoustic surveys conducted the previous day. For all six cruises we supplemented information on potential predators using variable-mesh gill nets placed perpendicular to shore. For each cruise, we collected up to 30 individuals of each species captured from the combined longline and gill net sets in the sampled bay. Fish were measured (TL, mm) and weighed (g) prior to removal of stomachs for dietary analyses. Stomach contents were analyzed in the laboratory to determine diet composition. Gut contents were sorted into gross taxonomic categories, enumerated and weighed (g). All fish prey items (fish tissue, otoliths and bones such as jaws, vertebrae, etc. as well as partially and fully intact fish prey) were shipped to a second laboratory. There fish were identified to species, estimated to size from hard parts based on published regressions, and counted.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: Following the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill, a group of herring research and monitoring projects were designed to improve predictive models of herring stocks in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska through observations and research. In particular, this dataset was generated to provide critical information to test the EVOS Herring Program’s hypothesis that Pacific herring recruitment during the overwinter period is controlled by top-down predation pressures, including the abundance and distribution of piscivorous fish. The objectives of this study were to: a) document diet composition of fish predators in and around juvenile herring schools; b) determine relationship between abundance of alternative prey and occurrence of herring in fish stomachs; and, c) model juvenile herring consumption by most important fish predators.These data will help fisheries managers develop better models of herring recruitment. In the future, these results may also help identify sites for future herring supplementation efforts and enable researchers to provide recommendations for other ways to manage the herring population.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Permission required from both Principal Investigators prior to use. Contact Dr. Mary Anne Bishop (Prince William Sound Science Center) and Dr. Sean P. Powers (University of South Alabama). . This material is based upon work funded by multiple entities, including the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed herein are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views or positions of funding entities. Standard scientific norms for attribution, credit, and potential co-authorship should be followed when using these data including to the Owners, Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council and other sources of funding. Please contact Drs. Bishop and Powers prior to use.

gml:TimePeriod.gml:description: November and March over three seasons.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: This data table contains information about the location, duration, depth, and type of fishing gear used to capture fish.
This data table contains the count or weight of prey items.
This data table contains full taxonomic information for prey species. The prey_taxa_ID field contains the foreign ID key related to the Prey.csv and PreyMeasurements.csv data tables.
This data table contains length and weight measurement of prey items.
This data table contains descriptions for prey condition codes used in the PreyMeasurements.csv data table.
This data table contains full taxonomic information for predator species. The fish_taxa_ID field contains the foreign ID key related to the Prey.csv and PreyMeasurements.csv data tables.
This data table contains information about the type and size of gear deployed to capture fish. The gear_type_ID field contains the foreign ID key related to the GearDeployments_2.csv data table.
This data table contains information about the cruise during which fish were captured. The cruise_ID field contains the foreign ID key related to the GearDeployments_2.csv data table.

This data table contains the catch data (2214 fish) that is associated with the final diet data report for this project. Data includes the length and weight measurements for captured fish sampled for stomach contents. The data table indicates which fish were sampled for contents.

This data table contains the complete catch dataset (2294 fish) and is included to provide users the complete catch dataset. Data includes the length and weight measurements and sex for captured fish. The hook size used and indication of whether individual fish stomachs were preserved is also included.
This data table contains information about the bay where the fish were captured. The bay_ID field contains the foreign ID key related to the GearDeployments_2.csv data table.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Data available in csv and acdb format for download in the Alaska Ocean Observing System (AOOS) Gulf of Alaska data portal.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Data were spot checked and examined for potential outliers.

The individual fish labels originally used by the PWSSC to denote all fish captured are not the same ones used by the Dauphin Island Sea Lab for the diet analyses. Both labels are a concatenation of bay, date, gear, type, rep, and fish number– but the formats are not consistent and the fish numbers do not always match.
Random quality assurance checks occurred throughout the sorting process to ensure sorter efficiency and effectiveness at identifying prey items.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Our field research took place in conjunction with combined, multi-project November and March cruises investigating aspects of overwinter juvenile herring ecology. Collection efforts for each cruise were aided by a second vessel performing acoustic transects that established locations and abundance of juvenile herring schools inside each bay. Depending on the year and cruise, our surveys were conducted in 5-10 bays. Our first, November 2009 cruise served as a trial run for our methodology. For that cruise we used two methods to capture potential fish predators: midwater trawls and longlines. Trawls were performed nocturnally (late evening and early morning) for durations of 25 to 45 min. We used a 7.6 m Marinovich otter trawl that measures 7.6 m wide (when fully opened), 8.1 m long and equipped with two otter doors (23 kg). Mesh size was 9 cm on the wings and body of the net and 3 cm at the cod end. The trawl was towed at 3 to 4 km h-1 at depths where fish schools were detected by the research vessel sounder (Furuno, 1 kW, 50 and 200 kHz transducers). This method yielded zero catch; therefore, it was eliminated from subsequent cruises. For longlines, we set one line at sunset followed by a soak time of three hours. Following its retrieval, we set a second, replicate longline approximately three hours prior to sunrise and spaced to avoid areas previously fished. Each longline consisted of a one skate (548.6 m) mainline with 200 gangions. Each gangion was ~60 cm long. For the November 2009 and March 2010 cruises, we used #13/0 offset-shank circular hooks baited with a non-local species of squid, while for the remaining four cruises we used approximately equal numbers of #13/0, #11/0 and #9/0 offset-shank circular hooks baited with a non-local species of squid. Longline catch per unit effort (CPUE) was calculated as fish caught per hook hour. For all six cruises we supplemented information on potential predators using variable-mesh gill nets. Gill nets were placed perpendicular to shore approximate to sunset and sunrise (one evening and one morning set per bay) and soaked for three hours. For the first two cruises (Nov 2009 and Mar 2010), gill nets were deployed at a depth of 10 to 20 m. For the remaining four cruises, gill nets were deployed on the bottom. For each of the bays sampled, we collected up to 30 individuals of each species captured from the combined longline and gill net sets. Fish were measured (TL, mm) and weighed (g) prior to removal of stomachs for dietary analyses. Stomachs were removed from fish specimens in the field, wrapped in cheese cloth along with a sample identification label containing a unique fish identification number, sample date, gear type and bay location. Stomachs were fixed in a 10% formalin and seawater solution and transported back to the PWSSC at which time they were transferred to 90% ethanol no sooner than 48 hours following the collection event. Prior to shipment to the Dauphin Island Sea Lab, the ethanol was decanted and the stomachs transferred to wet-lock boxes for shipment via FedEx. Upon receipt at Dauphin Island Sea Lab, samples were matched against the original catch list provided by PWSSC, transferred to 5 gallon buckets containing 90% ethanol for storage until processing occurred. The entire stomach was then weighed on a gram scale to 3 decimal places and the value recorded. The contents of the stomach were then removed as well as the stomach lining and the weights for each were recorded. Gut contents were then sorted into gross taxonomic categories, enumerated and weighed (g). Special attention was focused upon removal of fish tissue, otoliths and bones (jaws, vertebrae, etc.) as well as partially and fully intact fish prey items. All prey categories were stored separately from each other in 90% ethanol and all fish prey items were shipped to William A. Walker (Vashon Island, WA) for further analysis. Walker then sorted hard parts to species, provided an estimated count of species consumed and estimated size from hard parts based on published regressions (Wolff 1992, Frost and Lowry 1984, Harvey et al. 2000, Orchard 2000, Zeppelin et al. 2003). The following references were used for as a basis for the regressions: Frost, S.J. and L.F. Lowry. 1981. Trophic importance of some gadids in northern Alaska and their body - otolith size relationships. Fish. Bull. 79; 187-192. Harvey, J.T., Loughlin, T.R., Perez, M.A., and D.S. Oxman. 2000. Relationships between fish size and otolith length for 63 species of fishes from the Northeastern Pacific Ocean, 36 p. NOAA Tech. Rep. NMFS 150. Orchard, T.J. 2001. The role of selected fish species in Aleut paleo-diet. MA thesis, 228 p. Univ. Victoria, B.C. Wolff, G. A. 1982. Beak key for eight eastern tropical Pacific cephalopod species with relationships between their beak dimensions and size. Fishery Bulletin, U. S. 80: 357-370.(note: ** Decimal places are incorrect in the original equation presented for this species in Wolff (1982). Zeppelin T. K., D. J. Tollit, K.A. Call, T.J. Orchard and C.J. Gudmondson. 2003. Sizes of walleye pollock (Theragra chalcgramma) and Atka mackerel (Pleurogrammus monopterygius) consumed by the western stock of Steller sea lions (Eumetopias jubatus) in Alaska from 1998 - 2000. Fish. Bull. 102: 509 - 521.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The following procedure was used to convert Microsoft Office Access 2007 Database to csv file format and database relationships to JPG format on a Windows machine (date 1-4-2016). The procedures follow National Oceanographic Data Center (NODC) best practice (2016) for converting Access data to ASCII text format for archive: MS Access 2007-.mdb 1.Make copy of file to be converted in a working directory (this maintains the original time-stamp in ingest). 2.Open the file to be converted. 3.A list of the objects (tables, queries, forms, or reports) in the database should be on the left pane. 4.Select the object that contains the data you would like to start the conversion process with. 5. NOTE: You can only export one object with a single export operation. If there are subforms or subdatasheets, only the main form or datasheet is exported. The operation must be repeated for each object, subform, and subdatasheet. 6.Right click on the object. 7.Scroll down to Export. 8.Select Text File. 9.Specify the destination (data/1-data) and file name (typically the title of the object). 10.Check the box for Export data with formatting and layout and Open the destination file after the export operation is complete. 11.Click OK 12.Select the MS-DOS encoding for saving this file, Click OK 13.The new text document should open up. 14.Review the text document against the object in the database you converted. 15.Repeat steps 3 through 12 for the rest of the objects in the database file. 16.Once the entire database is converted a Database Relationship PDF/A needs to be created. Archiving Database Relationships Without Adobe Acrobat Pro installed: 1.Open the database file that has been converted to ASCII text. (The database file, not the text version of it.) If this has not been done yet follow the Step-by-Step process above then continue with these instructions.) 2.In the Microsoft Access Toolbar select Database Tools 3.Inside the Show/Hide toolbox select Relationships 4.Click Relationships under Show/Hide 5.An overview of the relationships in the database should now be visible. 6.There are two ways to view all the relationships. 1.Right-Click anywhere in the relationships window and select Show All 2.- OR - 3. 4.Under the Relationships Tools - Design toolbar and within the Relationships toolbox select All Relationships. 5.NOTE: If no relationships show up after these steps, then relationships might not exist for the database. 7.Adjust the objects into a coherent arrangement, the objects can be moved around and re-sized. (Usually the default arrangement doesn't make sense.) 8.Do a Print Screen on this page. 9.Minimize the Microsoft Access window and open Paint. 10.Paste the image. 11.In the Paint toolbar, select the dotted rectangle. 12.Encompass the chart of the Relationship. 13.Right click inside the box you just created. 14.Select Copy. 15.Minimize the current image and open a new image in Paint. 16.Paste the image into the new paint image. 17.Save the file as a JPEG (.jpg). Under Save as Type select JPEG (.JPG, .JPEG, .JPE, .JFIF). 18.File name should be relationship_chart and stored in data/1-data.
